results.title: What have I done to deserve this? = Que he hecho yo para merecer esto?
results.creator_credit: Pedro Almodovar, Tadeo Villabla, Kaktus S A and Tesauro S A
results.brief_description: Gloria is a housewife with attitude. She has to be: one son is a drug dealer, her youngest son is having an affair with the family dentist, her husband can’t excite her anymore, and her mother-in-law is determined to drive her crazy. To survive in the concrete jungle of Madrid, Gloria snorts cleaning powders and searches for sex with masculine strangers. This wickedly funny movie is an early feature by Almodovar and it revels in inverting and satirising the conventions of television soap opera and of the Hollywood “women’s film”. Absurd, fast-paced and stylistically innovative, “What Have I Done to Deserve This?” stars the fabulous Carmen Maura.

results.title: U.S. Sweat
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Gorewitz describes U.S. Sweat as a ‘cathartic reaction to social and personal upheavals’, he transforms images of the familiar American landscape into a nightmarish, ghostly vision. Recording throughout the South and in New York, he amassed footage that reflects the American experience. Country roads, gravestones and small-town main streets seen from a car window gradually give way to an ominous vision — saturated by Gorewitz’s signature image-processing techniques and lurid, fluorescent colors — of an America dominated by industry and the military. Called a tour-de-force by The New York Times, this is a propulsive, kinetic work of rich visual and aural textures.

results.title: Tosca: A Tale of love and torture
results.creator_credit: Trevor Graham, Patricia Lovell, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Film Australia
results.brief_description: It is 1999 and Opera Australia need a hit at the box office. They decide to stage Puccini’s masterwork- about a passionate young diva caught in the political turmoil of 19th century Rome- as a lavish production to lure the patrons. However, with a tight budget rehearsal time is cut to the bone and cast and crew are given just three weeks to prepare before the curtain is raised. Backstage drama and tensions build as opening night draws rapidly closer, Director Trevor Graham (who also directed ‘Mabo: Life of an island man’) was granted unrestricted access to film behind the scenes, from day one of rehearsals to opening night at the Sydney Opera House. This production stars Joan Carden as Floria Tosca and is conducted by Roderick Brydon.

results.title: Tosca
results.creator_credit: Gianfranco de Bosio, Italtelevisionfilm and Unitel
results.brief_description: This feature length production of Giacomo Puccini’s tragic love drama, “Tosca”, with libretto by Giuseppe Giacosa and Luigi Illica and adapted from the original play “La Tosca” by Victorien Sardou, is filmed on location at the magnificent Baroque Church of San Andrea, the luxurious apartments at the Palazzo Farnese and the bleak Castel Sant’Angelo, and features passionate performances by the three leading singers - Raina Kabaivanska (Floria Tosca), Placido Domingo (Mario Cavaradossi) and Sherill Milnes (Baron Scarpia). Also features the New Philarmonia Orchestra conducted by Bruno Bartoletti and the Ambrosian Singers as the chorus. Powerful, realistic and intensely dramatic this cinematic version captures the mood and emotions of one of Puccini’s most popular works. Sung in Italian with no English subtitles. Credits in Italian. NB: This video print is poor in quality in parts but is worth viewing for its unique presentation.

results.title: U.F.O's
results.creator_credit: Kenneth Knowlton, Lillian Schwartz and Bell Telephone Laboratories
results.brief_description: An imaginative experiment in film art, using computer graphics and synthesised music. Achieves a stroboscopic effect through motion, rhythm and form. Music by Emmanuel Ghent.

results.title: Tosca
results.creator_credit: Brian Large, Sylvano Bussotti, Radiotelevisione Italiana and National Video Corporation
results.brief_description: Giacomo Puccini’s opera in three acts with libretto by Giuseppe Giacosa and Luigi Illica is based on the original play written for Sarah Bernhardt by the French playwright Victorien Sardou. “Tosca” is a dramatic love story involving the ill-fated painter Mario Cavaradossi (Giacomo Aragall), his love, the singer Floria Tosca (Eva Marton) and the evil Chief of Police, Baron Scarpia (Ingvar Wixell) and set in Rome in 1800. Performed live at the magnificent amphitheatre of Arena di Verona, this made for television production features the Orchestra and Chorus of the Arena di Verona with conductor Daniel Oren and Chorus master Tullio Boni, along with grand scale set designs and period costumes by Fiorenzo Giorgi. Sung in Italian with no English subtitles. Includes booklet with English translation.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Brian Large, Sylvano Bussotti, Radiotelevisione Italiana and National Video Corporation

results.title: Toronto jazz
results.creator_credit: Don Owen, Roman Kroitor and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Toronto is regarded as the third largest jazz centre in North America. This film features a cross-section of jazz bands of that city: the Lenny Breau Trio, the Don Thompson Quintet and the Alf Jones Quartet. Their styles show creative self-expression, hard work, and improvisation.

results.title: Come and see = Idi i smotri
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Films of the great victory 1941-1945”.
Highly acclaimed Russian feature about a young boy, living in occupied territory, who joins the partisans to fight against the Nazis. An expressionistic work of great beauty that depicts abject horror, the narrative, based on true events, is framed as a coming-of-age story. The protagonist, a survivor through chance, is forced to repeatedly witness the awfulness of genocide, rape, destruction and evil, robbing him of youth, innocence and trust. Unforgettably poetic scenes reflect the brutality of victory, magnified through the eyes of a child. Adapted from the book by Ales Adamovich.

results.title: The Star = Zvezda
results.creator_credit: Nikolai Lebedev, Karen Shakhnazarov and Mosfilm
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Films of the great victory 1941-1945”.
Based on the book by Emmanuil Kazakevich, this film focuses on a group of Russian scouts in WW2, aiming to penetrate Nazi communications and thwart a major attack. Echoing the themes of Steven Spielberg’s “Saving Private Ryan” (2000), director Nikolai Lebedev presents war as chaotic, taxing and disorienting. At times quite claustrophobic, the film works best when presenting the dangerously fraught reconnaissance missions undertaken by the unit.

results.title: Ivan's childhood = Ivanovo Detstvo [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Andrei Tarkovsky, G Natanson and Mosfilm
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Films of the great victory 1941-1945”.
Tarkovsky’s prize-winning debut feature is an extraordinarily moving view of war and revenge. Twelve year-old Ivan is determined to avenge his mother’s death, and he joins a Russian regiment as a scout. His ability to slip through enemy lines more easily than an adult makes him useful to the army, but, as his missions become increasingly dangerous, it is decided that he must be removed from the front line. Ivan resists and convinces his commanding officers to allow him to carry out one last expedition. The monochrome photography depicts Ivan’s war in a series of memorable sequences, and contributes to making this film one of cinema’s great statements on war. Also available on VHS [311666].

Ivan resists and convinces his commanding officers to allow him to carry out one last expedition.
